text:
Raskolnikov only realized where he was when he found himself on the next street. He looked around and saw that he was near a tavern with steps leading down to the basement. Just then, two drunk men stumbled out of the tavern, arguing and holding each other up as they climbed the steps. Without thinking, Raskolnikov went down the steps. He had never been to a tavern before, but now he felt dizzy and really thirsty. He wanted a cold beer and thought his weakness was because he hadn’t eaten. 

He sat down at a sticky table in a dark corner, ordered a beer, and quickly drank the first glass. Immediately, he felt better, and his thoughts became clearer. “This is all nonsense,” he said to himself, feeling hopeful. “There’s nothing to worry about! It’s just my body acting up. A glass of beer and some dry bread, and suddenly my brain feels stronger, my mind is clearer, and I feel more determined! Wow, this is all so silly!” 

Even though he thought this way, he started to feel cheerful, as if a heavy weight had been lifted off him. He looked around at the other people in the room with a friendly attitude. But even then, he had a strange feeling that this happier mood wasn’t quite right. 

The tavern was mostly empty. Besides the two drunk men he had seen before, a group of about five men and a girl with a concertina had just left, making the room quiet and a bit lonely. The few people still in the tavern were...

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov, feeling giddy and tormented by thirst, enters a tavern for the first time, seeking relief in beer to clear his mind.
